event.description: Kotlin is a good language in many aspects. This talk will tell you about the main features that make it the right choice in case of fast development or prototyping. The real example of a hackathon project in Kotlin and comparison with equivalent parts of code in Java.

event.subject: Introduction to Kotlin
event.description: This is an introduction to the Kotlin programming language. We'll include a brief look at some awesome features of this modern language as well as the many benefits. Kotlin is a free and open source programming language designed by JetBrains. It can be used for Android, JVM server back-end, javascript, as well as native development such as IOS. Come and enjoy some refreshments while we discuss Kotlin, objectives, and plans for this group.

event.description:
Kotlin language brings tons of new concepts and features to your miserable programming life and it is really hard to use all of them in your daily duties. After almost two years of using Kotlin in production, the language itself can give me joy and satisfaction.

How is it possible? Because of its many small sweet sugars üç∞. In this talk, I would like to share with you my favorite Kotlin candies that I discovered when I was in need of writing robust and concise components for Android applications.

event.speaker: Ivan Morgillo
event.title: MobiConf 2018
event.subject: Kotlin coroutines ‚Äì A story of an old code base, dozens of reactive streams, a new language and a new way for concurrency.
event.description:
In a world dominated by RX and Java based code bases, JetBrains introduced Kotlin and coroutines - a simpler way to do multithreading.

This is the story of how I migrated an old project from a monolithic Java mess with improperly used RxJava to a cleaner architecture, based on Kotlin, coroutines and common sense.

We cover a number of examples, like JSON or XML builder's, data binding, configuration & template engines

event.title: Voxxed Days Ticino 2018
event.subject: Kotlin: lazy language for lazy people
event.description: A few years ago you had to work hard to succeed in some fields. Nowadays you don‚Äôt need to work hard but to work smart. So this means that most of the time laziness (of course not extremely) is useful for our productivity. On the other hand, laziness is extremely important when you work with a large amount of data and reduced space or power. In this talk we will try to cover all aspects of laziness in Kotlin: starting from lazy initialization of properties using delegates, lazy collections, sequences and, finally, laziness with coroutines. The main thing we would like to talk about is how to use this laziness and be productive with it. To see one more benefit of laziness in Kotlin we‚Äôll refactor a real application to use lazy calculations.

event.speaker: Paulien van Alst
event.title: Utrecht Java User Group
event.subject: How to build a Kotlin enterprise application.
event.description: Kotlin is the new JVM language where all the best practices of programming come together. Looking forward to discover a language that will support you in writing readable and understandable code in the fewest lines possible? Without any help of any extra libraries such as Lombok, Guava and even more, Kotlin will challenge you to write code that even the business analyst should be able to understand. With Kotlin you can finally focus on the business features you want to implement instead working on the language itself. In this workshop, you will build a simple webservice in Kotlin and hopefully see how easy it can be to write new business functionality. - Exercise 1 : (data) classes, collections and types - Exercise 2 : inheritance, interfaces and extension functions - Exercise 3 : how to integrate Kotlin with Spring

event.description: In this session, we‚Äôre going to explore how to create a standalone server application using Ktor. We'll work through a series of exercises to get familiar with Ktor, with the idea of build a web service for ordering food for our drone delivery app.

event.speaker: Lukas Lechner
event.title: droidcon Vienna 2018
event.subject: How 'Effective Java' influenced Kotlin
event.description: One of the most popular Java books is 'Effective Java' from Joshua Bloch, which describes how to avoid common mistakes, how to deal with Java's weaknesses, and how best practices for the language look like. When Jetbrains started to create a 'better Java' with Kotlin, a lot of ideas about how to make a better language came from the information of 'Effective Java' and lots of design decisions are based on the book. In this talk the audience will learn how the book influenced the language design and the compiler of Kotlin and in what way the book is deeply ingrained into the language.

event.speaker: Marcin Moskala
event.title: Mobile Optimazed 2018
event.subject: Kotlin Coroutines in action
event.description:
Kotlin Coroutines fascinate from its early beta. They are a new way to write asynchronous and non-blocking code. They can be thought of as light-weight threads without having to deal with all the problems that threads bring to the table.

In this talk Marcin will show how to use Kotlin Coroutines and what makes them so special and so efficient. He will also discuss if they are an alternative to RxJava.

Do you like Java but wish you didn‚Äôt have to write so much boilerplate code? Maybe it‚Äôs time for a switch. It is also 100% interoperable with Java and can be easily mixed in the same project.

In this presentation Antonis will try to guide you through the main features of Kotlin that make it so special and provide a short introduction to the language.

event.speaker: Nick Capurso
event.title: 360|AnDev July 2018
event.subject: Kotlin Coroutines: An Intro to Practical Use on Android
event.description:
Asynchronous programming has always been a challenging problem for Android developers. Any good solution has to gracefully handle errors, cancellation, chaining multiple actions together, handle thread swapping, and much more.

Kotlin‚Äôs coroutines are yet another option for asynchronous programming. However, unlike other popular contenders, coroutines meet all the previously mentioned requirements out-of-the-box, have a gentler learning curve, and don‚Äôt require you to write an absurd amount of boilerplate.

That said, learning any new asynchronous solution takes time and often comes with a period of trial-and-error until you have all the nuances figured out. Get a jumpstart on coroutines:

(1) Lessen the learning curve by getting the subtleties of coroutines out of the way early (2) Learn how to work coroutines into an existing app: easy places to start transitioning, interop with existing libraries, and reusing existing threading constructs (3) Learn how to easily support error handling, cancellation, and task chaining (4) Learn how to unit test coroutines

Get a head start on coroutines in your apps and easily write, test, and maintain asynchronous code like never before!

event.speaker: Oluwasegun Famisa
event.title: 360|AnDev July 2018
event.subject: Kotlin, Beyond the Basics
event.description:
In this talk, we will look at how you should not do things with Kotlin. For example, we will talk about misusing scoping functions like ‚Äúlet‚Äù, ‚Äúrun‚Äù, ‚Äúapply‚Äù, etc. and learn the right time to use which one while not overusing them. We will also talk about interoperability between Kotlin and Java. We will look at how not to do things when building APIs that may be consumed in Java ‚Äì things like top-level constant declaration vs constants within companion objects, making use Jvm* annotations in Kotlin vs not using them.

We will also talk about platform types and the potential harm they pose when calling Java code from Kotlin. We will also address another commonly overlooked topic ‚Äì the fact that Kotlin encourages a new paradigm of programming where you‚Äôre not thinking in terms of steps (imperative) but rather, in terms of functions applied to parameters (functional programming) and we still find ourselves doing things the wrong way.

event.speaker: Joshua Lamson
event.title: 360|AnDev July 2018
event.subject: Custom Drawing with Canvas in Kotlin
event.description:
When you‚Äôre creating a new View to display some complex data, it‚Äôs easy for the number of View objects you‚Äôre using to get out of control. Between elaborate shapes, shaders/colors, and text in specific places and orientations, using only Android Views and layouts can turn your layout into a dense, complicated mess. Luckily, there‚Äôs a better way to add all your customizations. What you need is a blank Canvas! (Literally, android.graphics.Canvas).

In this session, we‚Äôll delve into the details of using a Canvas to display anything you need in a truly custom way, explaining it all through simple examples written in Kotlin. You‚Äôll leave this talk knowing how override the behavior of View, ViewGroup, and Drawable to draw custom shapes, paths, and text on the Canvas.

event.speaker: Christophe Beyls
event.title: Kotlin User Group Hamburg
event.subject: Kotlin's hidden costs, revisited
event.description: Kotlin has become the new default modern programming language for many Android and backend developers. But exactly how much performance and code size are we sacrificing for making use of all the additional features this language provides compared to Java? We'll study the Java bytecode generated by the Kotlin compiler in various scenarios in order to find out which code constructs come with hidden performance penalties and learn how to become better Kotlin programmers. Some significant improvements in the recent versions of Kotlin will also be highlighted. This talk is based on the series of blog posts from the speaker and extends it in some areas.

event.speaker: Niklas Baudy

event.subject: Kotlin on Code Quality Tools
event.description: Some might have heard about code quality tools such as Checkstyle, PMD, Findbugs, Lint, Detekt and others but which ones are applicable to Kotlin? I'll list a bunch of tools, explain what they can do, touch on how they work and most importantly show you how you can start using them to be more productive and save a lot of time. With the help of these analyzers you can focus on coding conventions in your team, catch a few bugs and concentrate on what really matters when reviewing code

event.description: This talk is an introduction of how you can apply basic functional data types into your Kotlin applications. event.description: If you've ever seen kotlin code with words like "let, also, with, apply, run" thrown in and wondered what they're for, we'll cover them in this talk. We'll go over the basic usages of each of these standard library functions, the patterns that they can supplement, and how to extend their functionality to help consolidate your code!

We will see how can we use Kotlin's coroutines power and simplicity to run and manage several tasks in parallel in a very convenient way. This could also be a great and native alternative to RxJava without its steep learning curve and complexity.

event.description: We all know and love to use Kotlin in our Android apps, but did you know you can also use it to write your gradle build scripts? This talk will cover the pros and cons of migrating your buildscripts from Groovy to Kotlin. Is Kotlin more understandable than Groovy? Does it compile faster than Groovy? Is type safety and advantage in build scripts? This talk will also cover how the Kotlin Gradle DSL works under the hood.

event.subject: To inject or not inject - dependence injection in a Kotlin world
event.description: Dependency Injection via frameworks like Dagger were present in most modern Android projects. But then Kotlin happened. And since then a bunch of new libraries like Koin or Kodein appeared. Developers are even writing articles how to do DI without any framework. Some argue that those don‚Äôt even offer real dependency injection. Let‚Äôs look at that argument and compare the approaches. So, is there something wrong with Dagger & co. in Kotlin? Are they obsolete? What are the alternatives? Let‚Äôs dive in.

event.description: Over the last three months I ran a survey of the global Kotlin ecosystem. My goal was to learn how developers use and adopt Kotlin - either in work or side projects, or just for playing around, and what are some of the most popular resources for learning it. The survey was a great success, and gained over 2400 responses in total! The results are meant to become a resource for the Kotlin community. Something we can all look at for interesting insights that will also help drive adoption of Kotlin in our teams and organisations. To give you a taster, here‚Äôs a few questions I asked in the survey: How big is Android as a proportion of all Kotlin developers Are people happy naming libraries and tooling with K What are the favourite features of the language What kind of DSLs are people

event.subject: A deep dive into migrating from avtovalue to Kotlin data classes
event.description: AutoValue is a powerful tool provided by Google to generate Java immutable value classes. If you are migrating your project to Kotlin, data classes are the most direct way to replace it while keeping the same features. There are however trade-offs to take into account. In this talk we will introduce how we migrated our project from AutoValue to Kotlin data classes and how we dealt with the issues we encountered along the way. We will also discuss the advantages and disadvantages of each approach in terms of build time, apk size, method count and serialization time. After this introduction, we will deep dive into two topics: First, we will look into different serialization strategies available and how they perform. We will look into Gson, Moshi and Kotlinx.serialization libraries and explore their

event.title: droidcon italy
event.subject: From Java to Kotlin beyond Alt+Shift+Cmd+K

event.title: droidcon italy
event.subject: Better asynchronous programming with Kotlin Coroutines

event.speaker: Stefan May
event.title: droidcon italy
event.subject: How to write Gradle plugins (in Kotlin)

event.speaker: Amal Kakaiya
event.title: Android Makers Paris| 2018
event.subject: Travelling across Asia - Our journey from Java to Kotlin
event.description:
Kotlin brought new excitement to Android development, but the thought of converting a Java codebase to Kotlin can be quite daunting. Where do you start? What problems will you run into? How long will it take?

Deliveroo‚Äôs journey to Kotlin started over a year ago. This session will take you through their journey, the issues they‚Äôve faced and how Kotlin can improve your codebase, your app and your sanity.

event.speaker: Erik Hellman
event.title: Android Makers Paris| 2018
event.subject: Better asynchronous programming with Kotlin Coroutines
event.description: Android application development is inherently asynchronous. Even the simplest Android application requires the developer to track asynchronous callbacks of the activity, often leading to the infamous callback hell. In this talk, we will have a look at the latest addition to the solutions for dealing with asynchronous programming on Android; Kotlin Coroutines. We'll learn about what coroutines are, how they differ from other models and how to use it with Kotlin on Android.

event.speaker: Alexander Gherschon
event.title: Android Makers Paris| 2018
event.subject: Kotlinify your Gradle
event.description: The Gradle build tool is based on the JVM, so where does Kotlin fit in that ecosystem? We will see how Kotlin finds its place in that world, would it be by extending Gradle or by using Gradle Plugins with Kotlin.

event.speaker: Mitchell Tilbrook
event.title: Android Makers Paris| 2018
event.subject: Kotlin Backstage
event.description:
Kotlin offers a modern language design in contrast to Java, while at the same time maintaining full Java interoperably: Data classes, properties, delegation, inline functions, string interpolation and much more. But, if Java can't offer these features how come Kotlin can? What does Kotlin do to make it possible to use this Syntactic sugar?

In this talk, we will go backstage and dig into the Bytecode that Kotlin generates to make all the features we love work on a runtime that technically does not support them. We will look at the impact kotlin code generations has on method count. Get a deeper understanding of how Object and companion object work and see the implications of the use of either under different circumstances. Finally look at common patterns that can help reduce the size of both the bytecode and method count.

event.speaker: Simone Civetta
event.title: Android Makers Paris| 2018
event.subject: Reusable Cross-Platform Frameworks with Kotlin/Native
event.description: While building entire cross-platform apps might often turn out to be a bad idea, mission-critical client-specific logic can greatly benefit from an unique codebase, allowing code to be written - and tested - once. Since end 2016, Kotlin/Native can compile Kotlin code to a binary form, which can be embedded into a native app. In this talk you will learn why it makes sense, and how, to leverage these experimental features and build a cross-platform module reusable on both Android and iOS.

event.speaker: Wolfram Rittmeyer
event.title: Android Makers Paris| 2018
event.subject: Kotlin DSLs
event.description:
Kotlin is not just about null safety or data classes. Kotlin has much more to offer. One of the nice things is the ability to use Kotlin's features to create domain specific languages (DSLs).

In this talk you will see samples of DSLs you can use in your Android projects and learn how they work.

Kotlin DSLs are actually made of many simple Kotlin features - some of which you surely already use, some of which are a bit more obscure. But combined together they give us a powerful way to create nice DSLs.

event.speaker: Kirill Suslov
event.title: Android Makers Paris| 2018
event.subject: Explore Kotlin.Collections API
event.description: Kotlin is out here for a while now but many developers don‚Äôt use full power of it and write Java-style of Kotlin. let and apply are the only language features get adopted. This talk is aimed to overcome a small learning curve in one very common thing developers work every day with: collections. Backed by familiar Java collection API but supplemented by a set of handy functions, Kotlin collection API becomes a versatile tool that helps to develop faster and makes code clearer and nicer.

event.speaker: Christophe Beyls
event.title: Android Makers Paris| 2018
event.subject: Kotlin's hidden costs, revisited
event.description:
Kotlin has become the default modern programming language for many Android developers, with first-class support in Android Studio. But exactly how much performance and code size are we sacrificing for making use of all the additional features this language provides compared to Java?

We'll study the Java bytecode generated by the Kotlin compiler in various scenarios in order to find out which code constructs come with hidden performance penalties and learn how to become better Kotlin programmers. Some significant improvements in the recent versions of Kotlin will also be highlighted.

This talk is based on the series of blog posts from the speaker and extends it in some areas.

event.speaker: Paulien van Alst
event.title: OpenValue
event.subject: Hands on Kotlin workshop
event.description: Kotlin is the new JVM language where all the best practices of programming come together. Looking forward to discover a language that will support you in writing readable and understandable code in the fewest lines possible? Without any help of any extra libraries such as Lombok, Guava and even more, Kotlin will challenge you to write code that even the business analyst should be able to understand. With Kotlin you can finally focus on the business features you want to implement instead working on the language itself. In this workshop, you will build a simple webservice in Kotlin and hopefully see how easy it can be to write new business functionality.

event.speaker: David Lucas
event.title: Columbus Kotlin User Group
event.subject: fun Unit Testing with Baco
event.description: Join us as we review some of the current frameworks available for unit testing Kotlin including kotlin.test, JUnit 5, and Spek (yes, in Dutch it means Bacon). Examples will be provided for Kotlin JVM, Kotlin JS, and Kotlin Native.

event.speaker: Gabi Bornea
event.title: Kotlin User Group Bucharest
event.subject: Kotlin Explained Series - Functional Programming
event.description:
Kotlin its a strong type programming language which embraces both Functional and Object Oriented paradigms. This brings the power of the two "worlds" -> functional programming in the small and object oriented programming in the large.

In this first part of the series we are going to see how Kotlin (and arrow) embraces the functional programming paradigm to lead to more maintainable, easy to reason, succinct yet expressive and concurrent friendly applications.

event.speaker: Andrea Bresolin
event.title: GDG London
event.subject: Kotlin Coroutines: make your world more synchronous
event.description: In this talk we‚Äôll have an introduction to the coroutines in Kotlin. We‚Äôll see how they work, what we can do with them and how they can help us in making our code look more synchronous and easier to manage. We‚Äôll also briefly discuss about the interaction with existing code and we‚Äôll take a look at some of the ‚Äúcrazy‚Äù things that such a powerful tool allows us to do. The talk will be mainly focused on Android, but many of the concepts could probably be useful also in other platforms where Kotlin coroutines are available.

event.speaker: Zan Markan
event.title: GDG London
event.subject: The State of Kotlin
event.description:
Over the last three months I ran a survey of the global Kotlin ecosystem. My goal was to learn how developers use and adopt Kotlin - either in work or side projects, or just for playing around, and what are some of the most popular resources for learning it.

The survey was a great success, and gained over 2400 responses in total! The results are meant to become a resource for the Kotlin community. Something we can all look at for interesting insights that will also help drive adoption of Kotlin in our teams and organisations.

Kotlin est un langage de programmation qui s‚Äôadresse principalement aux utilisateurs Java. event.description: Kotlin as a language has a lot of similarities to Java in structure ‚Äî it's object-oriented, concise, type-safe, and designed for similar problems that Java solves with fewer NPEs. It is interoperable with Java, it brings in nice-to-have features out-of-box over Java with a functional programming flavor. It opens doors for other Java-like frameworks on the server, mobile, and browsers. In this session of 45 minutes, we dive into the basics of Kotlin and its features, comparison to Java and slowly understand the idea of mutual co-existence.

The common code is compiled for all platforms and can access platform-specific implementations of APIs and libraries. The platform-specific parts are also written in Kotlin and have access to the full set of features of the corresponding platform.

event.description:
Kotlin is going to be the standard language for Android. We already see lots of teams moving to this very promising language. But in JetBrains we just don't want to stop on that. So we are working on Kotlin.Native, the same language, different backend. And one of the most promising applications for this backend is iOS development.

In this talk I'll do short introduction into Kotlin language itself with description of some high level design ideas. Next step will be discussions around Native as a platform. I'll show you current complications with it and possible solutions. And finally we will go to iOS. You will see cross compiled Android/iOS example as well as example with just shared business logic. As a bonus I'll show you infinite possibilities about single language with all the parts, backend, frontend and two mobile apps.

event.speaker: Marharyta Nedzelska

event.subject: Kotlin: lazy language for lazy people
event.description: A few years ago you had to work hard to succeed in some fields. Nowadays you don‚Äôt need to work hard but to work smart. So this means that most of the time laziness (of course not extremely) is useful for our productivity. On the other hand, laziness is extremely important when you work with large amount of data and reduced space or power. In this talk we will try to cover all aspects of laziness in Kotlin: starting from lazy initialization of properties using delegates, lazy collections, sequences and, finally, laziness with coroutines. The main thing we would like to talk about is how to use this laziness and be productive with it. To see one more benefit of laziness in Kotlin we‚Äôll refactor a real application to use lazy calculations.

event.speaker: Dmitry Jemerov

event.subject: Developing multiplatform projects in Kotlin
event.description:
Kotlin 1.2, we‚Äôve added support for developing multiplatform projects. Multiplatform projects allow you to reuse the business logic written in Kotlin between all the components of your application ‚Äì backend code on the JVM, frontend code in JS, and also mobile apps. The common code is compiled for all platforms and can access platform-specific implementations of APIs and libraries. The platform-specific parts are also written in Kotlin and have access to the full set of features of the corresponding platform.

In this talk, we‚Äôll look at language and IDE features that support developing multiplatform projects, and at the libraries that can be used in such projects. As an example, we‚Äôll study a project that supports isomorphic HTML rendering, or, in other words, reuses the HTML building code between the frontend and the backend.

Coroutines is a new feature in Kotlin 1.1. It allows for writing an asynchronous code almost just like if it was regular/synchronous. This makes coroutines a great alternative to existing approaches for writing asynchronous applications.

In this session, I'll show how coroutines work in Kotlin. You'll learn about new syntax and implementation details. You'll find out about the differences between coroutines-based and reactive-based solutions. You'll also see a sample Spring-based application which uses coroutines.

Is this something you and your team should considering spending time to learn?

In this session we will go over what Kotlin is, what problems it solves, and what makes it stand out from other JVM languages. You‚Äôll come away with enough knowledge to decide if this is something you and your team should consider adopting.

event.description:
Kotlin on the Server! Kotlin on Android! Kotlin on the... browser?

Did you know, since version 1.1, the Kotlin compiler has offered a production-grade Kotlin-to-JavaScript transpiler? Using Kotlin/JS, we can not only use Kotlin for interacting with DOM elements, but we can also use Kotlin to communicate with server-side JavaScript such as Node.js! In this talk, we'll poke around the Kotlin transpiler and examine the javascript code that gets produced. event.speaker: Kevin Galligan

event.subject: Kotlin Multiplatform In Production
event.description:
Kotlin Native, with the ability to produce iOS code, was announced at KotlinConf 2017. With rapid progress on the runtime and tools, and intense community interest, several major architectural libraries have been released. KotlinConf 2018 will definitely see significant releases both, in both libraries and tools, and likely an official v1 of Kotlin Native.

2019 will be the year of significant application releases with a shared architectural base, powered by Kotlin multiplatform. This talk will be about the framework, how it compares (favorably) to other options, the current state of the ecosystem, and where developers eager to get involved in significant open source contributions can get started.

event.speaker: Roman Elizarov
event.title: Goto Conference
event.subject: Fresh Async With Kotlin
event.description:
Asynchronous programming is on the rise. Modern software systems are connected and constantly communicating. Programming languages are adding some form of asynchronous programming like async/await. However, Kotlin had taken a fresh approach to this problem with Kotlin Coroutines.

In this talk, we‚Äôll study various approaches to asynchronous programming, their evolution, differences and similarities. We‚Äôll see the problem with the traditional async/await approach that is based on futures/promises and how the Kotlin‚Äôs solution that is based on concepts of coroutines and continuations is giving us safer and easier programming model.

event.speaker: Roman Elizarov
event.title: Goto Conference
event.subject: Asynchronous Programming with Kotlin
event.description: This workshop covers asynchronous programming in Kotlin using coroutines. It starts with basics of asynchronous programming and its differences from blocking code and introduces concepts of suspending functions and coroutines. Dealing with the ecosystem of blocking code on JVM is covered in depth as well as best practices for managing cancellation of asynchronous operations. The workshop also covers more advanced topics of concurrent decomposition of work via futures, deep dive into coroutine contexts and includes an overview of Communication Sequential Process (CSP) approach and channels.

event.speaker: Kevin Most
event.title: √òredev
event.subject: Idiomatic Interop with Kotlin
event.description:
One of Kotlin's most valuable features is its 100% Java interop

However, your clean Java code might not look so clean from Kotlin, and vice versa

We will discuss strategies to write code in either language, to be consumed in either language, that is safe, elegant, and idiomatic

We will also touch on Kotlin's interop story for other targets (common, JS, and native) and what you can do there

event.speaker: Simon Harrer
event.title: √òredev
event.subject: Domain-driven Design with Kotlin
event.description:
You will learn about domain-driven design and its tactical design.

You will learn about implementing a tactical design in Kotlin using also lesser known language features.

You will learn a little bit about the rules in dungeons and drago

event.speaker: Marharyta Nedzelska
event.title: Devoxx Ukraine 2018
event.subject: Domain-driven Design with Kotlin
event.description: Microservice architecture is now a huge trend. All big organizations with millions of users are doing microservices. This means they have lots of channels of communication between services and need to send and get much data. At some point, you can find yourself in a situation where your current approach doesn‚Äôt provide you with efficient communications, you pay more, wait for more, lose more etc. Maybe it‚Äôs time to look at gRPC‚Ä¶ In this talk, we will cover the basics of gRPC, protocol buffers, and its usage. We will try to understand its pros and cons and where this approach could be used. We will also compare this approach with the alternatives. The most interesting about this talk is that we will have lots of practice. We will learn how to write .proto files, how to make effective communication between your microservices, and of course, write much code (in Kotlin)

event.speaker: Pamela Hill
event.title: GDG DevFest South Africa
event.subject: Level up in Kotlin
event.description: Kotlin has taken the Android world by storm since its official support in 2017. Many Android developers are coding or have at least an active interest in Kotlin. This talk aims to help Android developers level up their Kotlin skills, focussing on intermediate/expert language features such as coroutines, DSLs, and libraries/frameworks such as Koin for dependency injection, and Spek for testing.

event.speaker: Hadi Tok
event.title: GDG DevFest Istanbul
event.subject: RxJava ve Kotlin Coroutines, Kullanim senaryolari
event.description: RxJava bir √ßok kullanƒ±mƒ± olan g√º√ßl√º bir ara√ß. Asenkron i≈ülem ve fonksiyonel programlamanƒ±n bir √ßok √∂ƒüesini kullanƒ±ma sunuyor. Fakat Kotlin fonksiyonel programlama √∂zelliklerini ≈üimdiden, Asenkron i≈ülemleri kolayla≈ütƒ±ran ve ucuzla≈ütƒ±ran Coroutine'leri 1.3 versiyonu ile saƒülƒ±yor. RxJava ve Kotlinin bu √∂zelliklerinin kar≈üƒ±la≈ütƒ±racaƒüƒ±m.

event.speaker: Enrique L√≥pez Ma√±as
event.title: AndroidTO
event.subject: Kotlin/Native for Multiplatform Development
event.description:
Reliable multiplatform development has been the Holy Grail for Mobile Developers since its inception. Many frameworks did appear and disappear. Kotlin/Native has come strongly, and since it is still in Beta version there are some caveats about this. Is Kotlin/Native reliable for my app? Is it production-ready?

Come to this talk to learn what Kotlin/Native can do for you.

event.speaker: Francisco Est√©vez Garc√≠a
event.title: AndroidTO 2018
event.subject: Simple dependency management in Kotlin
event.description: In this talk we will discover how we can use just Kotlin features to inject dependencies through our codebase. Using this novel approach we'll introduce the concept of Type Classes, a unit of abstraction and configuration used to architect apps and libraries.

event.speaker: Zan Markan
event.title: AndroidTO 2018
event.subject: The State of The Kotlin Ecosystem
event.description: In early 2018 I ran a survey of the global Kotlin ecosystem. My goal was to learn how developers use and adopt Kotlin - either in work or side projects, or just for playing around, and what are some of the most popular resources for learning it. The survey was a great success, and gained over 2000 responses in total! The results are meant to become a resource for the Kotlin community. Something we can all look at for interesting insights that will also help drive adoption of Kotlin in our teams and organisations. To give you a taster, here‚Äôs a few questions I asked in the survey: How big is Android as a proportion of all Kotlin developers Are people happy naming libraries and tooling with K What are the favourite features of the language What kind of DSLs are people building with Kotlin and for what use-cases In my talk will answer all these questions, and more. But be warned, some answers might surprise you.

event.speaker: Svyatoslav Scherbina
event.title: AndroidTO 2018
event.subject: Using Kotlin to share code between iOS and Android
event.description: This talk is devoted to using Kotlin to share code between Android and iOS. It also covers Kotlin features and evolution making this possible and convenient. Kotlin Multiplatform Programming is a technology for multiplatform programming in Kotlin. It supports combining both common and platform-specific code in a single codebase with proper tooling enabled. Kotlin/Native is a technology for compiling Kotlin code to native binaries. Kotlin code has seamless interoperability with native platform (e.g. iOS) in this case. The speaker will describe how Kotlin/Native works, what is supported and what is not.

event.speaker: Marcin Moska≈Ça
event.title: AndroidTO 2018
event.subject: Superpowers of Property Delegation
event.description: Let's dive into possibilities that Kotlin delegation gives. Let‚Äôs discover property delegation and understand its superpowers.

event.speaker: Anton Keks
event.title: Mobius 2018
event.subject: Kotlin puzzlers, Vol. 2
event.description:
Kotlin is a marvelous language that makes programming on the JVM fun again. During the design phase of the language, it was said that Kotlin specifically tried to avoid some of the most famous Java Puzzlers. However, having so many advanced features, it cannot avoid introducing puzzlers of its own. This talk will present some of the more interesting nuances of syntax or language features with the help of small puzzler programs letting the audience guess their behavior. The mystery will then be revealed with an explanation in a fun way.

Having received an overwhelmingly good feedback from the previous version, Anton is ready with a set of completely new puzzlers to entertain you among all these really serious talks!

event.speaker: Svyatoslav Scherbina
event.title: Mobius 2018
event.subject: Using Kotlin to share code between Android and iOS
event.description:
This talk's main topic is how you can use Kotlin to share code between Android and iOS. We will also cover Kotlin platform development trends that make this easy and possible.

Kotlin Multiplatform Programming technology allows you to combine common and platform-specific code in a single codebase while also supporting tooling for this kind of development model. We'll see how this looks and discuss why it should be like this and not the other way around.

Kotlin/Native technology allows you to compile Kotlin into native code while also giving you an option to interact seamlessly with native platform (iOS, for example). We'll discuss what, why and how does (and does not) work.

event.speaker: Marcin Kozi≈Ñski
event.title: droidcon London 2018
event.subject: Kotlinise your Gradle Build Scripts and Plugins
event.description:
Are you using Gradle to build your Android app? Are you writing Gradle plug-ins? You'll be delighted to learn you can do it in Kotlin and it'll make your life better üôÇ/p>

Gradle Kotlin DSL is this new thing that aims to fix some annoyances you might have with your build scripts. And if you're thinking "Wait, what's Kotlin got to do with my build scripts? Ain't that just a JSON-ish Gradle specific text file?", then don't worry. Marcin will explain that in fact no, the build script is just code (spoiler: not Java‚Ñ¢Ô∏è Programming Language code, but close) and how Gradle Kotlin DSL makes it better./p>

He'll also take a pretty detailed look at how Gradle Kotlin DSL works for Android projects. Can you use it for your app's build script right now? Does it support the extra features (and complexity) that the Android Gradle plugin adds into the mix?/p>

If you're more (or also) interested in plugin development, writing them in Kotlin is not so new, but he'll quickly show how to do it anyway because it's great and you should try it!

event.speaker: Matthew Dolan
event.title: droidcon London 2018
event.subject: Why Effective Java Still Matters to Kotlin Developers
event.description: Effective Java by Joshua Bloch profoundly influenced the design of Kotlin yet by exploring a selection of "items" from the book you will see how it is still just as relevant to Kotlin developers today when we aim to write Effective Kotlin code. For example, consider how data classes implement equals, and you can see that it doesn't follow the rules suggested and as such is not always optimal.

event.speaker: Paco Estevez
event.title: droidcon London 2018
event.subject: Simple dependency management in Kotlin
event.description: In this talk you will discover how we can use just Kotlin features to inject dependencies through our codebase. Using this novel approach you'll learn about the concept of Type Classes, a unit of abstraction and configuration used to architect apps and libraries.

event.speaker: Kevin Galligan
event.title: droidcon London 2018
event.subject: Kotlin Multiplatform Architecture
event.description:
Code sharing options for mobile have existed for years, but most tend to be relatively obscure (Rubymotion), difficult to use (C++), or limited in scope or developer interest (J2objc). Kotlin Multiplatform will emerge as an option that allows significant sharing of logic and architecture, while still allowing easy fully native integration, and have overwhelming developer community interest. This talk explores the current ecosystem, what popular libraries and tools are available, what‚Äôs coming soon, and how to get started building multiplatform for mobile.

To talk review people. The status of Kotlin and multiplatform will change dramatically between now and October, so while the talk will be on this topic, it‚Äôs hard to predict exactly where you‚Äôll be by then. Kevin has spent 2 years working on a J2objc solution to sharing architecture and has switched to Kotlin. He's recently released a functional demo of SQLite and SQLDelight running on iOS and is currently working on a formal SQLite shared library, which should be published later this month.

event.speaker: Marcin Kozi≈Ñski
event.title: droidcon London 2018
event.subject: Kotlinise your Gradle Build Scripts and Plugins
event.description:
Are you using Gradle to build your Android app? Are you writing Gradle plug-ins? You'll be delighted to learn you can do it in Kotlin and it'll make your life better üôÇ

Gradle Kotlin DSL is this new thing that aims to fix some annoyances you might have with your build scripts. And if you're thinking "Wait, what's Kotlin got to do with my build scripts? Ain't that just a JSON-ish Gradle specific text file?", then don't worry. Marcin will explain that in fact no, the build script is just code (spoiler: not Java‚Ñ¢Ô∏è Programming Language code, but close) and how Gradle Kotlin DSL makes it better.

He'll also take a pretty detailed look at how Gradle Kotlin DSL works for Android projects. Can you use it for your app's build script right now? Does it support the extra features (and complexity) that the Android Gradle plugin adds into the mix?

If you're more (or also) interested in plugin development, writing them in Kotlin is not so new, but he'll quickly show how to do it anyway because it's great and you should try it!

event.speaker: Jorge Ortiz Fuentes
event.title: droidcon London 2018
event.subject: Workshop: Let's Migrate to Gradle Kotlin DSL
event.description: Gradle is an awesome and very powerful build tool. It is key to tune your build and even more relevant to achieve the promised karma of continuous integration. However, one of its biggest "shortcomings" is that in order to extract any drop of power juice, you need to know and use Groovy. Nothing against Groovy, but it is just another language and, very likely, one that you don't use very often. But worry no more! Now you can use the same language that you enjoy and use it when you write the code of your apps: Kotlin. During this workshop Jorge will start with a walk through some of the most relevant features of gradle. Then you will learn how to transform the gradle configuration of a project to use Kotlin DSL. You will finish by extending that configuration with a new functionality taking advantage of writing it in Kotlin. Join Jorge to kotlinize your gradle!

event.speaker: Hadi Hariri
event.title: droidcon London 2018
event.subject: Workshop: Creating DSLs in Kotlin
event.description: One of Kotlin's powers is the ability to easily create Domain Specific Languages which can be used in your application. In this workshop you'll learn the basics of Kotlin functions and see how you can combine a series of features to create DSLs that can be used to represent a variety of things in your apps, ranging from configuration to domain logic.

event.speaker: Daniel Gonz√°lez Reina
event.title: Dublin Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Create a Kotlin-React App
event.description: In this meetup we'll learn how to create a web app using the Kotlin wrappers for React. We'll see how to take advantage of Kotlin features to write expressive code that will compile to a React application.

event.speaker: Marie Katrine Ekeberg
event.title: Oslo Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: Testing in Kotlin and YOU
event.description: What options do you have for testing your code in Kotlin? Some people will probably just jump straight to JUnit as a testing framework, but did you know you that Spek offers an alternative approach with a domain specific language (DSL) for tests? Your choice of tools doesn't stop here. You have alternative assertion libraries, mocking frameworks and more that are different from what you may be used to in Java. The builder pattern is also even simpler in Kotlin, which make creating test data builders work like a charm. We will look at these topics and more! With examples ranging from small utility classes to integration tests with Spring.

event.speaker: Javier Moreno Aleman, Tammy Tyberg
event.title: New York Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: NYC Subway Sign with Kotlin and Raspberry Pi
event.description: A few months ago we were looking through a gift guide and saw one of those nice-looking, real-time Subway signs that you put on a coffee table or a bookshelf. We decided to get one, then saw the price (+$300) and thought, "Wait a minute, we're pretty sure we can just build this for less money." So after grabbing one of the many Raspberry Pis lying around the office, and with Kotlin as the weapon of choice, we embarked on a new project: Your own personal subway sign for (way) under $300.

event.speaker: Ryan Cooke
event.title: New York Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: Building Backend Microservices in Kotlin
event.description: Ryan will describe how Kotlin has gone from a hackathon experiment to the language of choice for backend service development at N26. He will present thoughtful strategies on how to build adoption based on learnings from false-starts introducing other languages to the stack. And with a bottoms-up approach, Kotlin eventually advanced into his firm's Android applications. N26 is now an active member in the Kotlin community in Europe and is focused on applying emerging features such as coroutines to their event driven systems.
